questions.text: Which of the following is true about thalamus?

choices.text: Thalamus is the sensory gateway to cerebral cortex
Thalamus is the largest part of telencephalon
Y-shaped band of fibers divides the thalamus into 4 subdivisions
Thalamus is the motor gateway from the cortex

questions.solution:
The thalamus is being called the sensory gateway to the cerebral cortex as all information that reaches the cortex is processed by the thalamus.

The thalamus is a large collection of neuronal groups within the diencephalon; it participates in sensory, motor, and limbic functions. 

Other Options:  

Option B: Thalamus is the largest part of the diencephalon.

Option C: Y shaped band of fibers divide the thalamus into 3 subdivisions- anterior, medial, and lateral group.

Option D: Thalamus is the sensory gateway to the cortex.

The ventroposterior nuclear complex of the thalamus represents the main termination site for ascending somatosensory information (which includes pain) in the diencephalon.

Thalamic nuclei have been divided into

A. Specific (Relay) nuclei because they have a specific and selective relationship with a particular portion of neocortex

  1. Medial geniculate body for auditory information
  2. Lateral geniculate body is for information from retina
  3. Ventroposterior group for somatosensory information

B. Nonspecific nuclei project to several cortical and subcortical regions

questions.text: Which of the following is called ''the window of limbic system'' ?
questions.solution:
The amygdala has been called the “window” through which the limbic system sees the place of the person in the world.

The amygdala receives neuronal signals from all portions of the limbic cortex, as well as from the neocortex of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, especially from the auditory and visual association areas.

Components of the limbic system

  • The term limbic lobe, or limbic system, is applied to the part of the brain that consists of a rim of cortical tissue around the hilum of the cerebral hemisphere and a group of associated deep structures—the amygdala, the hippocampus, and the septal nuclei.
  • The papez circuit is a closed neural circuitry that starts and ends in the hippocampus, which forms the basal ganglia. It is also known as the medial limbic circuit. The components of papez circuit are-

Mnemonic-He Man Ate Cat

  • He-Hippocampus
  • Man-Mamillary body
  • Ate-Anterior thalamus
  • Cat-Cingulate gyrus

Related Pearl: Components of limbic system

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the Papez circuit?
questions.solution:
Anterior nucleus of the thalamus is a component of Papez circuit, which is important for short term memory.

Papez Circuit (refer figure):

The limbic system was studied by James Papez who described the Papez circuit. It consists of:

Mnemonic for components of Papez circuit-He Man Ate Cat

  • He-Hippocampus
  • Man-Mamillary body
  • Ate-Anterior thalamus
  • Cat-Cingulate gyrus

The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which are in turn connected to the anterior nuclei of the thalamus by the mammillothalamic tract. The anterior nuclei of the thalamus project to the cingulate cortex, and from there, connections to the hippocampus complete a complex closed circuit.

The boundaries of the limbic system were subsequently expanded to include the amygdala, septum, basal forebrain, nucleus accumbens, and orbitofrontal cortex.

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
questions.solution:
Major reward centres are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus. Therefore, stimulation of those areas will promote a sense of reward. 

It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, a weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.

questions.text: In response to an increase in plasma osmolality, ADH is released in blood. Which of the following sites contains the receptor to detect a change in plasma osmolality?
questions.solution:
Osmoreceptors that detect any change in plasma osmolality and control ADH secrection, are located in anterior hypothalamus.

questions.text: The main organ for biological clock is _______.
questions.solution:
In the hypothalamus, the suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker, or time clock, for circadian rhythms.

The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, and these inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract).

One output of the pacemaker goes to the pineal gland, a gland within the brain that secretes the hormone melatonin.These neural signals cause the pineal gland to secrete melatonin during darkness but not during daylight.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features will be most likely seen in a patient with an anterior hypothalamic lesion?
questions.solution:
Lesions involving the anterior and preoptic hypothalamic regions cause paradoxical vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and hyperthermia.

The anterior hypothalamus activates mechanisms of cooling the body when the temperature increases via the reflex response.

Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, thereby cooling the body. Lesions in this region cause hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimes reaching 43°C (109.4°F).

questions.text: Diurnal variation of ACTH is controlled by which of the following regions?
questions.solution:
Diurnal variation of ACTH depend on suprachiasmatic nucleus.

The secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This effect results from a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the suprachiasmatic nucleus of hypothalamus that cause cortisol secretion.When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the categorical hemisphere?
questions.solution:
Functions of the categorical hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy.

Human language functions depend more on one cerebral hemisphere than on the other. This hemisphere is concerned with categorization and symbolization and has often been called the dominant hemisphere. However, the other hemisphere is specialized in the area of spatiotemporal relations.

The concept of “cerebral dominance” and a dominant and non-dominant hemisphere has been replaced by, one hemisphere for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere) and one for visuospatial relations (the representational hemi­sphere).

The representational cerebral hemisphere excels in nonlanguage skills, especially spatial perception, and artistic and musical talents.

questions.text: Lesions in which nucleus of the hypothalamus produce a voracious appetite and rage?

choices.text: Upper region of the lateral hypothalamus

questions.solution:
A lesion in the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, the satiety center, is responsible for producing a voracious appetite and rage.

Lesions in the upper region of the lateral hypothalamus produce a profound loss of appetite.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area.
questions.solution:
It is a cross section of brain stem at pons.

  • A is a periaqueductal gray matter which also consists of raphe nucleus.
  • Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates.

Other marked structures are

B: Corticospinal tract

C: Medial lemniscus

D: Medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are ___________.
questions.solution:
Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

Increased osmolality acts via osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus.

The decreased plasma volume, as in hemorrhage, acts via
1. Renin-angiotensin system
2. Baroreceptors in heart and blood vessels.

The intake of liquids during a meal is known as prandial drinking. The increase is known as learned or habit response but is not understood completely.

The following factors are thought to play a role
1. Increase in plasma osmolality due to food absorption
2. Action on hypothalamus by one or more gastrointestinal hormones
